claim.hypothesis: The entrepreneurship rate in a country is negatively associated with the country’s median age.
claim.hypothesis_location: p. 154 Corollary 3; p.157 empirical implications: implication 5; also discussed in the abstract.
claim.statement: A  one standard deviation decrease in median age (equal to 3.5 years in 2010) results in a 2.5 percentage point increase in the entrepreneurship rate, which is over 40 percent of the mean entrepreneurship rate across countries (equal to 0.061 in 2010).
claim.statement_location: p. S167, section V. Empirical Implementation (B. Country-Level Analysis); also discussed in the abstract.

data.source:
entrepreneurship: Global Entrepreneurship Monitor; the GEM data is checked against: Flash Eurobarometer Survey on Entrepreneurship.
demographics: US Census Bureau’s International Data Base
data.notes: The total number of observations is 1.3 million, the number of country-year cells is 393, and the number of country-age-year cells is 17,554. The entrepreneurship rate can be constructed at each cell level. China was excluded from the study.

method.description: The study examines how demographic structure influences entrepreneurship, regressing country-level entrepreneurship rates on median age
method.steps:
1.Get entrepreneurship data defined as managing and owning a business up to 42 months old that pays wages. Aggregate the data to construct entrepreneurship rates at the country-year level.
2.Get population data and calculate median age for each country-year.
3.Estimate a regression and weight observations are weighted by the number of individuals who make up each country-year cell. Include year dummies as controls. Standard errors clustered at the country level are in brackets.

results.summary: A one–standard deviation (3.5-year) reduction in median age raises the entrepreneurship rate by 2.5 percentage points, equivalent to roughly 40% of the sample mean (0.061) across countries.

numerical_results.p_value: not stated; p was not stated explicitly, but the result is calculated using the estimates from column 3 of table 2, and regression coefficients on median age there are significant at 1 percent level
numerical_results.statistical_significance: not stated; p was not stated explicitly, but the result is calculated using the estimates from column 3 of table 2, and regression coefficients on median age there are significant at 1 percent level
